metadata.title: Development of high strength and toughness nano-SiCp/A356 composites with ultrasonic vibration and squeeze casting

sections.text:
The nano-SiCp/A356 Al-matrix composites containing 2 wt.% nano-SiCp were synthesized with solid-liquid mixed casting method. The effects of ultrasonic vibration (UV) treatment and squeeze casting on refinement were studied and the role of nano-SiCp distribution on refinement was focused. Results show that both of the secondary dendritic arm spacing (SDAS) of α-Al grains and the size of eutectic Si phase decrease with the increase of the UV time and the applied pressure of squeeze casting. When UV is applied for 3 min, the SDAS of α-Al in composites is 8.1 μm, which is reduced by 49 % than that of A356 matrix alloy. The mean diameter and aspect ratio of eutectic AC CE
PT ED
Si phase in composites are 0.92 μm and 2.33, and they are reduced by 42 % and 32 % respectively than those of A356 matrix alloy. When the applied pressure of squeeze casting is 400 MPa, SDAS of α-Al in composites is 6.9 μm, which is reduced by 55 % than that of A356 matrix alloy. Both the processes of UV and squeeze casting can affect the refining effects by regulating the distribution of nano-SiCp. The better the dispersion of nano-SiCp is, the better the refinement of αAl and eutectic Si phase can be achieved. The mechanical properties of 2 wt.% AMNCs are improved with the increase of UV time and applied pressure, which is consistent with the refinement of the composites’ microstructure. Keywords Aluminum matrix composites; Nano-SiCp; A356 matrix alloy; Refinement; Ultrasonic vibration; Squeeze casting

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Aluminum Matrix Composites (AMCs) tend to replace traditional metal materials due to their
superior mechanical properties and wear performance, and are preferred for applications in fields of aerospace, shipping, automobile, sports and chemistry (Lakshmi et al., 1998; Natarajan et al., 2009). Since AMCs with m-scale reinforcement particles would sacrifice the ductility of the matrix alloys, it is of interests that aluminum matrix composites reinforced by nano-particles (AMNCs) could take all these advantages while maintaining the ductility of matrix alloy (Akbari et al., 2015). Therefore, the research of AMNCs has received extensive attention. However, the performance of AMNCs is mainly affected by the distribution of nanoparticles and evolution of matrix microstructure. Therefore it is necessary to conduct in-depth research on AMNCs.
It is known that reinforcement particles could strengthen the matrix directly according to the
Orowan strengthening mechanism as particles inhibit the dislocation movement (Correia et al.,
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
1997). But the influence of reinforcement on microstructure was also reported. Choi et al. (2012) studied preparation of Al-20Si alloy and the effects of different contents of γ-Al2O3p on properties and microstructure. The refinement of primary and eutectic Si was achieved by γ-Al2O3p at the same time. It is distinct that the refining effect of reinforcement particles is obtained based on the fine distribution of the particles. However, the problems of particle dispersion and wettability make it difficult to add the particles to the molten metal. Hinojosaa et al. (2004) found that the presence of SiCp in the A356 matrix could not affect the secondary dendrite arm spacing (SDAS) of α-Al significantly as preferential nucleation of eutectic Si was observed around SiCp clusters. The poor distribution can be mainly attributed to the limited effectiveness of mechanical stirring, as high surface energy is encountered when dealt with fine particles (Kaisarlis et al., 2018). High energy ball milling, which was more commonly used in the solid-state method to synthesize AMCs (Knowles et al., 2014; Kollo et al., 2011), was also used in liquid methods to reach a mixture of reinforcements and other powders at first. The mixture powders would provide a new interface, i.e. Al/Al interface, to replace the interface between ceramic reinforcements and Al melt when added into Al melt. And then a pre-mixing between reinforcements and the Al melt would be obtained by mechanical stirring. However, when dealt with nano-particles, it could be difficult to release the reinforcements from the mixture in the melt as the high specific surface area of nanoparticles would lead to low wettability in Al melt. Therefore, assisting process is necessary to improve the distribution of nano-particles in the melt.
UV treatment is commonly used as an assisted process in casting process of AMNCs. When
UV is applied to the preparation of AMNCs, high pressure and high temperature within micro area could be achieved due to the cavitation effect. The implosive impact caused by the high pressure
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
and temperature could disintegrate the agglomerations of nano-particles and improve the wettability between ceramic particles and aluminum melt (Jia et al., 2016; Yang et al., 2004). UV treatment can also contribute to the evolution of microstructures of molten aluminum alloys. Nie et al. (2012) prepared SiCp/AZ91 composite materials with different volume fraction with ultrasonic method, and found that the addition of nano-SiCp has obvious refining effect on the primary phase (α-Mg) and the second phase (Mg17Al12) as UV was applied. Jian et al. (2005) stated that a globular (non-dendritic) microstructure of α-Al grains was achieved when a continuous acoustic vibration was applied to the aluminium melt. In the research of Mg99.0−xNixY1 (Yang et al., 2018), the long period stacking ordered structure in Mg alloys could be refined and homogenized by ultrasonic treatment, and mechanical properties of the alloy were significantly increased due to the refinement of the LPSO structure.
Squeeze casting is a process that external pressure is applied after pouring the melt into the
mold, which can effectively eliminate casting defects and improve the mechanical properties of the materials (Lü et al., 2013). Different forming pressure could lead to the evolution of microstructure, as in the study of the preparation of Al-Si-Mg alloy by squeeze casting, it was found that the grain size of α-Al decreased from 67 μm to 46 μm while the pressure increased from 30 MPa to 90 MPa (El-Khair et al., 2005). Maleki et al. (2009) prepared LM13 alloy and found that the SDAS of α-Al decreased from 47 μm to 34 μm while pressure of 100 MPa was applied. However, the effects of squeeze casting on the particle distribution and microstructure of AMNCs are rarely reported.
In this work, nano-SiCp was used as reinforcement, and A356 alloy was used as matrix
material. A 2 wt.% nano-SiCp/A356 composite was prepared by means of liquid ultrasonic
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
vibration process and squeeze casting method, and the influence of ultrasonic vibration and squeeze casting on microstructure of the composites and the role of nano-particles in this process were studied.

sections.heading: 2. Experimental procedures
sections.text:
The matrix alloy was A356 (Al-7Si-0.4Mg). β-SiC particles which had an average diameter
of 40 nm were used as reinforcements. And pure aluminum powders with an average diameter of 65 μm were used for preparing composite granules. Commercial pure Al, pure Mg and Al-24.5Si master ingots were also used as raw material. The composites were synthesized with a solid-liquid mixed casting method, the process details could be found in our previous study (Yuan et al., 2018; Wu et al., 2018).
Nano-SiC particles were calcinated at 850 ℃ for 2 h to form an oxidation film on the
surface. The removing of the impurities and gases in SiC powders was obtained at the same time. Then high energy balling milling (HBM) was carried out in a QM-3SP4 planetary mill, of which the milling vessels was vacuumized and filled with stainless steel balls with diameter of 10 mm. Nano-SiCp/Al composite granules were fabricated through HBM by milling the mixture of 6 wt.% nano-particles and balanced pure Al powders. Finally composite granules with a metallic luster and diameters of 0.8~2 mm were obtained.
In the casting process, a balanced amount of Al-24.5Si master alloy were melted in a graphite
crucible and pure blocks of Al and Mg were used as raw materials. The preheated temperature of composite granules were 250 ℃. After the alloy was fully molten at 720 ℃, mechanical stirring was applied to the melt with a graphite stirrer of 4 blades. Composite granules were added into the stirring vortex, and the melt was cooled down to 680 ℃. The stirring was kept up for about 15
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
min and the stirring speed was about 180 rpm. After the stirring process the melt was heated up to 720 ℃ and held for 30 min. Then the molten metal was degassed with pure argon gas for 10 min. After that, the ultrasonic vibration was introduced into the melt and kept for different UV times. A titanium ultrasonic horn with Φ20 mm provided ultrasound waves with maximum power output of 2.8 kW and frequency of 20 kHz. The composite melt was poured into a preheated permanent steel mould of 250 ℃ after UV and then squeeze-cast with different applied pressures to fabricate casting ingots, with length of 100 mm and 30 mm in diameter. The squeeze casting machine was controlled by a numerical control system. The displacement of punch mould was 50 mm and the moving speed was 25 mm/s. The pressure would be held for 30 s after the punch mould finishing the movement, and the initial pressure was half of the target pressure, as shown in Fig. 1.
Fig. 1 Pressure curves The microstructure and mechanical properties of SiCp/A356 were also studied. A DMM480C optical microscopies (OM) and a JEOL JSM-7600F scanning electron microscopy (SEM) were used to investigate the distribution of SiC nanoparticles and the evolution of microstructure in detail. The samples of OM and SEM were mechanically polished and etched with 0.5 vol.% HF
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
for 10 s. The average SDAS of the α-Al and the average mean diameter of eutectic Si phase were measured from more than 10 OM and SEM micrographs respectively by Imagine Pro Plus Software. The average SDAS was sampled from 100 X optical micrographs and the mean diameter of eutectic Si phase were sampled from 5000 X SE images. The mechanical properties of A356 and its composites were also studied as corroborative evidence of microstructure refinement. The tests were carried out on a SHIMADZU AG-IC100KN tester. And the strain rate is 0.001 s-1. The corresponding samples were fabricated according to ASTM standard B557M-15. Diameter and gauge length of samples were 6 mm and 30 mm respectively. The data of mechanical property values were taken from an average of 5 samples. To ensure the repetitive of the mechanical properties, five samples were tested for each material.

sections.heading: 3.1 Effects of UV time on microstructure of AMNCs
sections.text:
M
AN
US CR
IP T
figures.
Fig. 2 Optical image of 2 wt.% AMNCs prepared with UV for (a) 0 min; (b) 0.5 min; (c)1 min; (d) 2 min; (e) 3 min; (f) 5 min
Fig. 3 shows the statistics of SDAS of AMNCs while the data of A356 matrix alloy are listed as a contrast. A refinement effect of α-Al can be attributed to UV treatment directly as the SDAS of A356 matrix alloy decreases with the increase of UV time. When UV time is 5 min, the SDAS of A356 matrix alloy is 13.7 μm, reducing from 16.2 μm of no UV specimens. Almost no
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
difference of SDAS among AMNCs and A356 matrix could be inferred from the figure when UV is not used. This phenomenon indicates that the presence of nano-SiCp in the A356 Al matrix does not affect this parameter of α-Al SDAS significantly if no assisted process was applied in the casting method. Since UV is introduced, it can be found that the SDAS of α-Al decrease rapidly both in 1 wt.% AMNCs and 2 wt.% AMNCs. When UV is kept for 3 min, the SDAS of α-Al in 2 wt.% composites is 8.1 μm, which is reduced by 49 % compared with the untreated composites. It can be also inferred that the grain refining effect of reinforcement particles associates along with nano-SiCp content. The SDAS of α-Al decreases with increase of nano-SiCp content if UV is used, i.e. when UV time is 5 min, the SDAS of α-Al in 2 wt.% composites is 8.0 μm, which is reduced by 19 % compared with 1 wt. % AMNCs, and is also reduced by 41 % than that of A356 matrix alloy. However, reason for refining effect of UV under addition of nano-SiCp is not clear at this stage as the distribution of nano-particles could not be observed in detail due to their tiny size.
Fig. 3 Secondary dendritic arm spacing of A356 matrix alloy and its composites prepared with different UV times
In fact, the inhomogeneous area shown in the optical micrographs is caused by serious
agglomerations of nanoparticles, as shown in Fig. 4a. It can be found that serious agglomerations
AC
CE
PT ED
M AN
US CR
IP T
exist and there is a tendency that the size of particle agglomerations is reduced when UV time extended to 1 min (Fig. 4c). It is of interests that the eutectic Si phase located in or around the agglomerations is changed significantly in morphology. Compared with other ones located in regions poor of SiCp, eutectic Si phase with SiCp dispersed around is significantly modified to fine islands from acicular ones. Fig. 4d, 4e and 4f show the microstructure of 2 wt.% AMNCs prepared with UV for 2 min, 3 min and 5 min. Compared with Fig. 4a and 4b, the agglomeration phenomenon has been ultimately eliminated and the distribution of nano-SiC particles has been further improved. It can be seen that small clusters of particles remain and a small amount of acicular eutectic Si phases still exist when the UV time is 2 min. When UV time reaches 3 min, the small cluster is no longer existed, and the eutectic Si phases are effectively refined and change into coralline ones. According to the eutectic Si phase in Fig. 4e, eutectic Si phase with a mean diameter of 0.92 μm and an average aspect ratio of 2.33 is obtained. When UV time is further extended to 5 min, the morphology of the sample changes little. In summary, the distribution of nano-SiCp is immensely improved as the agglomeration phenomenon is eliminated gradually with increase of UV time, and finally uniform dispersion of nano-particles is obtained. At the same time, the morphology of the eutectic Si phase gets refined obviously with the increase of UV time, as shown in Fig. 5.

sections.heading: 3.2 Effects of applied pressure on microstructure of AMNCs
sections.text:
Fig. 6 shows the optical micrographs of 2 wt.% AMNCs prepared with different applied
pressures of squeeze casting. UV treatment of 3 min is used. The dendrites are obvious coarse ones when no pressure is applied (Fig. 6a). And the SDAS of α-Al is 13.1 μm. The refinement effect of α-Al gets strengthened with the increase of applied pressure as shown in Fig. 6b, 6c and 6d. At the same time, the area of eutectic regions also decreases since the grain number of α-Al increases. In Fig. 7, it can be inferred from variation of SDAS that squeeze casting method can contribute to the refinement of α-Al in A356 matrix alloy. When the applied pressure is 400 MPa, the SDAS of α-Al in A356 matrix alloy is 13.1 μm, reducing from 15.3 μm of specimens prepared with 0 MPa. And the refinement effect also works on AMNCs. When the applied pressure of squeeze casting is 400 MPa, the SDAS of α-Al in 2 wt.% AMNCs is 6.9 μm, which is reduced by 27 % compared with 1 wt.% AMNCs, and is also reduced by 55 % than that of A356 matrix alloy prepared with gravity casting. The SDAS of α-Al decreases with increase of nano-SiCp content at a same applied pressure, i.e. when the applied pressure is 100 MPa, the SDAS of α-Al in 1 wt.% composites is 10.8 μm, which is reduced by 29 % than that of A356 matrix alloy prepared with AC CE PT ED M AN
US CR
IP T
gravity casting. And the SDAS of α-Al in 2 wt.% composites is 8.1 μm, which is reduced by 49 % than that of A356 matrix alloy prepared with gravity casting. It indicates that nano-SiC particles could strengthen the refining effect as the variation of refinement increases with increase of the nano-SiCp content.
Fig. 6 Optical image of 2 wt.% SiCp/A356 squeezed with (a) 0 MPa; (b) 100MPa; (c) 200 MPa; (d) 400 MPa

Fig. 7 Secondary dendritic arm spacing of A356 matrix alloy and its composites prepared with different applied pressures
Fig. 8 shows the SEM images of 2 wt.% AMCs prepared by squeeze casting with different
pressures. It could be inferred from the figures that the area of eutectic regions decreases rapidly with the increase of applied pressure, which is consistent with the increasing number of Al grains. The mean diameter and aspect ratio of eutectic Si phase is 1.2 μm and 2.8 respectively with traditional casting (Fig. 9), i.e., at 0 MPa. When the applied pressure is 100 MPa, the mean diameter and aspect ratio of eutectic Si phase in composites are 0.92 μm and 2.33 respectively. However, little change of the morphology can be observed on eutectic Si phase with the further increasing of pressure, as shown in Fig. 9.

sections.heading: 3.3 Refinement mechanism
sections.text:
UV treatment can effectively refine α-Al and eutectic Si phase of AMNCs. On the one hand,
some insoluble micro particles are activated due to ultrasonic cavitation effect, which can serve as crystal nucleus of α-Al and eutectic Si phase. Partial undercooling, which can contribute to heterogeneous nucleation of α-Al and eutectic Si, is caused by the heat absorption effect of the growing cavitation bubble. As a result, the refining effect of α-Al and eutectic Si is achieved (Lan et al., 2004; Su et al., 2012). On the other hand, UV treatment can exert an influence on the refining effect of α-Al and eutectic Si phase through improving the distribution of nano-SiCp. With the cavitation effect of UV treatment, as shown in Fig. 10, particles agglomerated at the bottom of the ultrasonic horn will be disintegrated into small clusters by the impact which is formed by the collapse of cavitation bubble. Then these particle clusters will be broken up and aggregated repeatedly until the Van der Waals force between nanoparticles is overcome (Sha et al., 2012). And finally uniform distribution of nano-particles is achieved. At the same time, as the circulation formed by acoustic streaming effect can act on the whole melt, the dispersed nanoparticles can be AC CE PT ED
M AN
US
CR
IP T
distributed more uniformly, and the nano-aggregates in the areas with weak cavitation effect can be brought to the area below the ultrasonic horn due to the circulation.
Fig. 10 Sketch of particles’ dispersion with UV The refining effect of nano-SiCp on α-Al and eutectic Si phase depends on the solidification process of Al-Si matrix composite. A356 alloy is a kind of hypoeutectic aluminum alloy, the type of the growth process of α-Al is dendritic growth. During the solidification the majority of nanoSiCp cannot be captured by the solidification front due to poor wettability between SiCp and α-Al. As shown in Fig. 11, the repelled SiCp tend to segregate between the dendrites, at the same time eutectic Si phase will separated in residual liquid around nano-SiCp (Wu et al., 2001).
Fig. 11 Sketch of solidification process of (a) A356 matrix alloy; (b) AMNCs
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US
CR
IP T
Nano-particles, which are pushed along by the solidification front, can produce significant
Smith-Zener pinning effect (Ferry et al., 2005), the inhibiting effect of microscopic particles on the interface movement. And the growth of α-Al grains and eutectic Si phase will be impeded significantly. The resistance force Pz caused by nano-particles could be estimated by Equation (1).
3
2
v
z
F P
r
  (1)
In Equation (1), Fv is the volume fraction of SiCp and r is particle radius. 𝛾 is the grain
boundary energy of the dispersed particles. According to Equation (1), the smaller the particle radius is, the greater the Zener resistance is, and the greater the inhibiting effect on grain growth is. For the tiny size of nanoparticles, the effective r value should be determined by their actual dispersion. Fine distribution of nano-particles can lead to great refinement effect of α-Al and eutectic Si phase. UV treatment can effectively improve the distribution of nanoparticles in aluminum melt and reduce the r value in Equation (1), thus enhancing the pinning effect and effectively refining the α-Al and eutectic Si phase of the composites.
The grain refinement effect of squeeze casting pressure can be partly attributed to the high
heat transfer coefficient between aluminum melt and metal mold due to the applied pressure (Wang et al., 2017; Aweda et al., 2009). According to the Clausius-Clapeyron theorem (Venkatesan et al., 2018), an increasing pressure leads to an increase in the freezing point of the material. The greater freezing point will result in more fine-grained microstructure. The increase of freezing point can be calculated in Equation (2).
( )

Where Tf is freezing point of the composite and P is applied pressure. Vl is volume fraction of
AC CE
PT ED

liquid phase and Vs is volume fraction of solid phase. ΔHf is latent heat of fusion. According to Equations (2), a higher applied pressure of squeeze casting could lead to the increase of freezing point, which can also improve the cooling rate of the casting and results in the refinement of microstructure of the composites.
The effect of controlling squeeze pressure on the microstructure and morphology of
composite materials is indirect. The morphology of microstructure can also be affected indirectly by regulating the distribution of nano-particles with squeeze casting. As the applied pressure increases, the number of grain boundaries in the composites increases and the distribution of nanoparticles has been improved on the macro level.

sections.heading: 3.4 Mechanical properties
sections.text:
Fig. 12 and Fig. 13 show the results of room temperature mechanical properties of A356
matrix alloy and its composites which was prepared with different UV times and applied pressure of 100 MPa. It is clear to see that ultimate tensile strength (UTS) of A356 matrix alloy and its composites have increased with the extending of UV treatment. The minor strengthening effect of UV on A356 matrix alloy may be mainly attributed to the grain refinement and homogenization effect explained in section 3.3. When UV time is 5 min, UTS of A356 matrix alloy is 220 MPa, increasing from 202 MPa of the untreated specimens. By contrast, the variation of UTS on different UV times is much larger with AMNCs. When UV time is less than or equal to 1 min, the low UTS of AMNCs may be attributed to the serious agglomerations of SiCp as shown in Fig. 4a and 4b. When UV time is more than or equal to 2 min, the UTS of AMNCs shows rapidly increase compared with the composites treated with UV of 1 min. The elimination of agglomerations and fine particle distribution shown in Fig. 4e and 4f may result in particle strengthening effect AC CE PT ED
M
AN
US CR
IP T
according to Orowan strengthening mechanism (Wang et al., 2014) as particles inhibit the dislocation movement. And the contributions of the great refinement of α-Al and eutectic Si phase shown in Fig. 3 and Fig. 5 to the strengthening effect can be explained by Hall–Petch equation (Hall, 1953; Petch, 1953). It can be also inferred that the UTS of A356 matrix alloy and its composites increase with the increase of SiCp content, which fits the fact that higher SiCp content results in better refining effect with adequately dispersed nano-particles. When UV time is 3 min, the UTS of 2 wt.% AMNCs is 258 MPa, which is increased by 35 % compared with the untreated composites, and is also increased by 27 % than that of A356 matrix alloy. The change rule of Yield Strength (YS) is similar to that of the UTS of the composites. When UV time is 3 min, the YS of 2 wt.% AMNCs is 144 MPa, which is increased by 56 % compared with the untreated composites, and is also increased by 62 % than that of A356 matrix alloy prepared without UV.
Elongation (EI) of A356 matrix alloy and its composites is shown in Fig. 13. The increase of
EI may be mainly attributed to the refinement of eutectic Si phase as the harmfulness of cutting the matrix by long acicular eutectic Si is reduced. At the same time, grain refinement of -Al and fine distribution of nano-SiC particles would also lead to the increase of EI. When UV time is 3 min, the EI of 2 wt.% AMNCs is 5.5 %, which approximately maintains the ductility of A356 matrix alloy prepared with UV treatment of 3 min and applied pressure of 100 MPa.

Fig. 12 UTS and YS of A356 matrix alloy and its composites prepared with different UV times
Fig. 13 EI of A356 matrix alloy and its composites prepared with different UV times
Fig. 14 and Fig. 15 show the results of room temperature mechanical properties of A356
matrix alloy and its composites which were prepared with different applied pressures and UV treatment of 3 min. It could be inferred that the UTS of A356 matrix alloy and its composites have increased with the increase of applied pressure. Other than the approximate straight-line which represents the UTS of A356 matrix alloy, the UTS of AMNCs shows rapidly increased as applied pressure is used and further increase are obtained as the applied pressure increase. The YS and EI of 2 wt.% AMNSs increase with the increase of applied pressure as well, as shown in Fig. 15. In Fig. 14, the lines which represent UTS of 1 wt.% AMNCs and 2 wt.% AMNCs are almost AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US
CR
IP
T
paralleled from 100 MPa to 400 MPa. It shows almost no significant effect of particle strengthening as the applied pressure increase, which is consistent with the similar particle distribution of 1 wt.% AMNCs and 2 wt.% AMNCs within micro area due to the same applied UV time. But the great refinement of α-Al and the reduction of the area of eutectic regions result in Hall–Petch strengthening effects and good ductility (Fig. 15). The improvement of particle distribution on macro level due to the increase of grain number can also contribute to the increase of ductility with the applied pressure increases. When the applied pressure is 400 MPa, the UTS, YS and EI of 2 wt.% AMNCs are 268 MPa, 163 MPa and 7.4 %, which are increased by 24 %, 33 % and 68 % respectively compared with the composites prepared with gravity casting, and are also increased by 29 %, 83 % and 71 % respectively than those of A356 matrix alloy prepared with gravity casting.
Fig. 14 UTS of A356 matrix alloy and its composites prepared with different applied pressures AC CE

Fig. 15 YS and EI of 2 wt.% AMNCs prepared with different applied pressures The low UTS of AMNCs prepared with gravity casting may attributed to the casting defects. Porosity is easy to form in the gravity casting of AMNCs due to gas involving with the addition of nano-particles, as shown in Fig. 16. It can be inferred that pore deficiency exists when composites are prepared with gravity casting method and is effectively eliminated when squeeze casting is used. The porosity rate can be characterized with the density of AMNCs as shown in Fig. 17
The low density of AMNCs is consistent with the optical images of Fig. 16a as pore
deficiency exists when squeeze casting is not used. And the increase of density indicates the elimination of the casting defects as shown in Fig. 16b.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusions
sections.text:
1) The nano-SiCp/A356 composites containing 2 wt.% nano-SiCp is synthesized by a method
combined UV treatment and squeeze casting. Nano-SiC particles are dispersed well in the matrix and no serious agglomeration is observed.
2) Both the processes of UV and squeeze casting can affect the refining effects on -Al and Si
phases by regulating the distribution of nano-SiCp in composites. The better the dispersion of nano-SiCp is, the better the refinement of α-Al and eutectic Si phase can be achieved.
3) When UV time is kept for 3 min, SDAS of α-Al in 2 wt.% AMNCs is 8.1 μm, which is
reduced by 49 % than that of A356 matrix alloy. The mean diameter and aspect ratio of eutectic Si phase in composites are 0.92 μm and 2.33, and they are reduced by 42 % and 32 % respectively than those of A356 matrix alloy.
4) When the applied pressure of squeeze casting is 400 MPa, SDAS of α-Al in 2 wt.% AMNCs
is 6.9 μm, which is reduced by 55 % than that of A356 matrix alloy. The area of eutectic
AC CE
PT ED
M AN
US
CR
IP T
regions decreases rapidly with the increase of applied pressure.
5) The UTS, YS and EI of 2 wt.% AMNCs are improved with the increase of UV time and
applied pressure, which is consistent with the refinement of the composites’ microstructure.

referenceMentions.context: Introduction Aluminum Matrix Composites (AMCs) tend to replace traditional metal materials due to their superior mechanical properties and wear performance, and are preferred for applications in fields of aerospace, shipping, automobile, sports and chemistry (Lakshmi et al., 1998; Natarajan et al., 2009).

Introduction Aluminum Matrix Composites (AMCs) tend to replace traditional metal materials due to their superior mechanical properties and wear performance, and are preferred for applications in fields of aerospace, shipping, automobile, sports and chemistry (Lakshmi et al., 1998; Natarajan et al., 2009).

metadata.abstractText: The nano-SiCp/A356 Al-matrix composites containing 2 wt.% nano-SiCp were synthesized with solid-liquid mixed casting method. The effects of ultrasonic vibration (UV) treatment and squeeze casting on refinement were studied and the role of nano-SiCp distribution on refinement was focused. Results show that both of the secondary dendritic arm spacing (SDAS) of α-Al grains and the size of eutectic Si phase decrease with the increase of the UV time and the applied pressure of squeeze casting. When UV is applied for 3 min, the SDAS of α-Al in composites is 8.1 μm, which is reduced by 49 % than that of A356 matrix alloy.
